candidates.title: Did a KGB Agent Confirm That the Sex Pistols Were Backed by the USSR to Destabilize the West?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 9 May 2017, Facebook page "The Church of PUNK" shared an article reporting that a KGB agent admitted the band the Sex Pistols were an operation backed by the former Soviet Union to destabilize Western democracy:
The April 2015 article reported that at the time it was published, a former KGB agent had just disclosed the punk rock plot:
Alexandrei Varennikovic Voloshin, a retired KGB agent, has admitted this week on National Russian Television (NTV) that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was behind the creation of the 1970s punk scene and financed major punk bands such as the Sex Pistols, the Clash and the Ramones.
The USSR government at the time spent hundreds of millions of rubles on this covert operation destined to create utter chaos and pervert the Western youth to nihilist, anti-establishment and anti-american ideologies he explained in an hour long interview broadcast on national television.
There is no truth to this story; World News Daily Report states on its own disclaimer page that all of the content on the site is fictional:
WNDR assumes however all responsibility for the satirical nature of its articles and for the fictional nature of their content. All characters appearing in the articles in this website  even those based on real people  are entirely fictional and any resemblance between them and any persons, living, dead, or undead is purely a miracle.
candidates.description: A Facebook page for punk fans recirculated an old (and fake) story that the Sex Pistols were a KGB plot to foment dissent in the West.

result.explanation: The provided text from Snopes explicitly debunks the claim in the news caption.  Snopes identifies the source of the claim as a satirical website (World News Daily Report), which explicitly states its content is fictional.  Therefore, the claim that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were a Soviet operation is false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes fact-check explicitly labels the claim as false.  The Snopes article quotes the disclaimer from World News Daily Report, confirming the story is fictional. The Snopes article also quotes the alleged statement from the supposed KGB agent.

final_result.explanation:
The original news caption claims that a KGB agent admitted the Sex Pistols were a Soviet operation to destabilize Western democracy.  Both internal and external checks strongly refute this claim.

Internal validation finds no visual evidence in the image to support any of the entities mentioned in the caption (KGB, Sex Pistols, Soviet Union, Western democracy). The image simply shows a person singing into a microphone; there is nothing to connect it to the Sex Pistols or any political operation. The confidence score for the internal check is 0, indicating a complete lack of visual support for the caption's claim.

External validation uses a Snopes fact-check as a source.  Snopes definitively debunks the claim, tracing its origin to a satirical website (World News Daily Report).  The Snopes article highlights the satirical nature of the website and quotes the disclaimer from World News Daily Report, confirming that the story is entirely fictional.  The high confidence score of 10 from the external check reflects the strong evidence from a reliable fact-checking source.

There is no disagreement between the internal and external checks; both independently demonstrate that the caption is false. The image provides no visual evidence to support the caption's narrative, and external research confirms that the claim is a fabrication from a satirical news source.  The complete lack of supporting evidence from both internal visual analysis and external fact-checking leads to a high confidence score (10) in the conclusion that the caption is out of context.  Therefore, the final verdict is that the caption is demonstrably false and completely out of context with respect to the provided image.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validations confirm the news caption is false and out of context. The image shows a singer, unrelated to the claim about the Sex Pistols and a Soviet operation.  External fact-checking confirms the claim originates from a satirical website.
